item.title: OKCupid row: Hurrah for our less than perfect matches! Online dating isn't a science
item.description: {"title":"OKCupid online dating row: Hurrah for our less than perfect matches!","summary":[" Yes, the all-important 'match' rating - a figure that is supposed to tell users how well they will connect with other daters - became an invention.","Rudder added, \u201cMaybe people just like each other because they think they\u2019re supposed to?","It can\u2019t be predicted by simple maths."],"source":"telegraph.co.uk"}

item.title: WATCH: 'Electrical storm' of thoughts deep within a zebrafish's brain as 80,000 neurons fire off
item.description: {"title":"WATCH: 'Electrical storm' of thoughts deep within a zebrafish's brain as 80,000 neurons fire off","summary":["A new technique, called light-sheet imaging, was able to capture 80 per cent of the fish\u2019s neurons in action, showing the electrical storm within its brain in unprecedented detail.","The study could allow researchers to better understand the \u2018rules\u2019 of the brain activity by mapping exactly which neurons are responsible for certain movements.","Scroll down for video\u00a0 In this image neurons in a zebrafish brain are coloured by the direction of motion they are associated."],"source":"dailymail.co.uk"}

item.title: People say techies are invading San Francisco. They said the same about my immigrant grandfather
item.description: {"title":"People say techies are invading San Francisco. They said the same about my immigrant grandfather","summary":[" I\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve begun to worry that San Francisco is slipping back into the past.","If you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re not from here, you might not notice it amid the sparkle of new office towers, the pageant of initial public offerings and the people wearing glasses that can also make phone calls and tell you the euro-dollar exchange rate.","Growing up in San Francisco as a third-generation Chinese American, I remember learning about the city\u00e2\u0080\u0099s uneasy relationship with new arrivals."],"source":"washingtonpost.com"}

item.title: Hummingbirds edge out helicopters in hover contest
item.description: {"title":"BBC News - Hummingbirds edge out helicopters in hover contest","summary":["This is according to a study comparing hummingbirds with one of the world's most advanced micro-helicopters.","Researchers found that - in terms of the power they require to lift their weight - the best hummingbird was over 20% more efficient than the helicopter.","Lead researcher Prof David Lentink, from Stanford University in California, explained that the flight performance of a hummingbird - the only bird capable of sustained hovering - was extremely difficult to measure."],"source":"bbc.com"}

item.title: Analysts rush to lift Twitter price targets on results blowout
item.description: {"title":"Analysts rush to lift Twitter price targets on results blowout - Market Extra","summary":["Late Tuesday, the shares jumped more than 30% after the company\u00e2\u0080\u0099s adjusted profit and revenue surpassed expectations, and its outlook on full-year revenue was also better than a previous estimate.","Analysts had also been holding their breath over the tally for monthly active users.","Twitter edged past expectations for 267 million monthly active users with a count of 271 million."],"source":"marketwatch.com"}

item.title: Vince Cable says UK will have 'fleets' of driverless cars as he admits he doesn't even own a Sat Nav
item.description: New driverless technology will see "fleets" of satellite controlled vehicles on Britain's roads within years, Vince Cable has claimed as he admits he doesn't even have a basic SatNav device installed in his own car. The Business Secretary has announced ...

item.title: Twitter zooms 25% on strong sales and mobile growth
item.description: Things are looking up for Twitter -- or at least, for its stock price. Twitter (TWTR, Tech30) shares surged 25% in premarket trading Wednesday after it posted strong second-quarter sales. Twitter's better-than-expected quarterly report helped allay fears ...

item.title: Flipkart's Bansals nearly as rich as Infosys co-founders
item.description: BANGALORE: The Bansals of Flipkart — Sachin and Binny — now boast of a combined net worth in excess of $1 billion, inching closer to that of Bangalore's iconic tech billionaires N R Narayana Murthy and Nandan Nilekani of Infosys. The fresh $1-billion ...

item.title: Warding Off Lions With Mobiles Shows African Technology Boom
item.description: If Emily Parsitau wanted to light her home to ward off lions and intruders, she had to walk for an hour to buy kerosene at the nearest store. Now, she uses a SIM card. The farmer’s four-roomed home in Kisamis, a rural area on the fringe of Kenya’s Rift ...

item.title: IPhone-Ready Apps Mean Teens Tracked Without Calling Home
item.description: Becca Ludlum knows better than to expect her teen son, Michael, to call home as he skateboards from the mall to the park to friends’ homes on long summer days. Ludlum instead relies on a downloadable smartphone application called Life360 that uses ...

item.title: Say goodbye to Facebook Gifts
item.description: The social network has decided that its Gifts feature is not working and that from now on it will instead focus on helping others promote their own gifts and goods via the site. When Facebook Gifts went live in the US in September 2012, it actually sold ...

item.title: India set to become Amazon's fastest-growing market: CEO Jeff Bezos
item.description: MUMBAI: Amazon.com on Wednesday said it will invest a further $2 billion in India just a day after the country's largest e-tailer Flipkart attracted $1 billion of fresh funds, raising the stakes in a nascent but fast-growing e-commerce sector. Amazon ...

item.title: Want to Colonize an Alien Planet? Send 40,000 People
item.description: This story was updated at 1:00 p.m. EDT on July 28. If humanity ever wants to colonize a planet beyond the solar system, it's going to need a really big spaceship. The founding population of an interstellar colony should consist of 20,000 to 40,000 people ...
